DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term to represent the description of the histologic results related to cellular differentiation of the bladder tumor.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Bladder Urothelial Carcinoma Histologic Cellular Differentiation
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The most common morphologic subtype of urinary bladder carcinoma (over 90% of cases).  It arises from the transitional epithelium.  It most often affects males in their sixth and seventh decades of life.  Hematuria is the most common symptom at presentation.  Pathologic stage is the strongest predictor of survival._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The most common morphologic subtype of urinary bladder carcinoma (over 90% of cases).  It arises from the transitional epithelium.  It most often affects males in their sixth and seventh decades of life.  Hematuria is the most common symptom at presentation.  Pathologic stage is the strongest predictor of survival.

Concepts.definition: A carcinoma that arises from the urothelial lining of the bladder.  It is the most common morphologic type of urinary bladder carcinoma. It usually affects males in their sixth and seventh decades of life.  Hematuria is the most common symptom at presentation. Pathologic stage is the strongest predictor of survival.

Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.

In cancer, refers to how mature (developed) the cancer cells are in a tumor. Differentiated tumor cells resemble normal cells and tend to grow and spread at a slower rate than undifferentiated or poorly differentiated tumor cells, which lack the structure and function of normal cells and grow uncontrollably.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: indication of the presence and extent of disease.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not characterized in any other way.: Used to indicate the presence of something or someone.: A microscopic finding indicating that a tumor exhibits more than one line of histologic differentiation.
